shot_context.definition: Front-foot, off-side stroke with emphasis on timing, balance, and directional control.
constraints_acknowledged: no ball/bat-face/bat-path inference beyond provided metrics
sequencing derived only from explicit peak frames
shot_context.bat_backlift_angle_definition: Measured relative to the vertical axis (0° = vertical; larger = laid back further). Small values indicate compact, near-vertical backlift.

what_went_right: Compact backlift during load (bat stayed near-vertical relative to the vertical axis).
Clear shift toward the front foot through the downswing window (weight transfer moved progressively forward).
Peak timing followed a trunk → lead arm → pelvis pattern, which suits a placement-focused cover drive.
Ready position showed a stable base with minimal forward trunk lean.
what_to_improve: Lead knee remained notably flexed during the downswing window, which may reduce front-leg 'bracing' and directional control at impact.
Hip–shoulder separation was substantial into the downswing window; if mistimed, this can pull the swing across the line rather than through extra cover.

P2_load_backlift_and_preparation.observation: Backlift angle was 3.90° relative to vertical at frame 229, indicating a compact, near-vertical backlift.
P2_load_backlift_and_preparation.interpretation: A compact backlift supports late adjustment and precise bat presentation, which aligns with a classical cover drive where timing and control outweigh power intent.

P3_weight_transfer_for_front_foot_drive.observation: During P3 (frames 230–259), WT fell from 0.508 to 0.198 (FrontBar mean 0.668).
P3_weight_transfer_for_front_foot_drive.interpretation: That pattern indicates the body mass is moving onto the front foot through the downswing, consistent with a front-foot drive where balance over the front leg supports timing and directional control.

sequencing_archetype_cover_drive_fit.observation: Peak frames: trunk 237, lead arm 253, pelvis 259 (order: trunk → lead arm → pelvis).
sequencing_archetype_cover_drive_fit.interpretation: This 'arm-dominant' peak order is compatible with placement-focused strokes: the trunk and arms can guide bat acceleration and face stability without an early pelvis-driven power sequence.

P3_front_leg_mechanics_control.observation: Lead knee flexion during P3 averaged 50.50° (min 45.00°, max 56.85°).
P3_front_leg_mechanics_control.interpretation: A more flexed lead knee through the hitting window can reduce a firm front-side 'post', potentially affecting stability and the ability to hit straight through the off-side line. This is a control cost more than a power cost for a cover drive.

hip_shoulder_separation_timing_risk_note.interpretation: Separation can contribute to bat acceleration, but on a classical cover drive it must stay 'in sync' with the step and head stability; otherwise it can drag the swing across the line. (data-supported, research-limited)

wt_alignment_rule_applied.note: WT series longer than pose series; used the first overlapping range from the start as instructed.

visuals.note: No images generated or described. Use frame indices below to locate moments in your existing extracted frames.

sequencing_inputs_used.note: Any pre-computed sequencing labels/scores were ignored as instructed.

goals: Keep the cover drive control-first: stable base, compact load, smooth forward move, and a braced front side.
Preserve the current arm-dominant sequencing while improving front-leg stability through the hitting window.

drills.name: Shadow cover-drive with freeze at 'end of P3'
drills.how: Rehearse the shot without a ball. Move from load into the downswing and freeze for 2 seconds at the end of P3, feeling a tall front side and stable head position.
drills.ties_to_data: Targets the observed lead-knee flexion pattern in P3 while preserving the compact backlift.

drills.name: Step-and-hold weight transfer (front-foot base)
drills.how: From stance, step forward into the drive base and hold balance for 3 seconds before swinging. Repeat with small variations in step length to train stability under different lines.
drills.ties_to_data: Reinforces the forward WT trend observed in P3 and helps keep the movement controlled rather than rushed.

drills.name: One-hand lead-arm guidance swings (placement intent)
drills.how: Short, controlled one-hand swings (lead hand) focusing on presenting the bat straight through the off-side. Keep the load compact and avoid forcing hip rotation.
drills.ties_to_data: Builds on the arm-dominant peak order while reducing reliance on pelvis-driven power.

warmup: 10–15 slow shadow reps emphasizing compact backlift and balance.
main: 3 x 6 reps each drill, rest long enough to keep quality high (placement intent).
skill_transfer: Finish with controlled throwdowns aiming for timing and a straight bat path feel (no power intent).

coach_view.one_line_summary: Compact pick-up, a clear move onto the front foot, and an arm-led swing — now tighten the front-leg brace so the bat goes even straighter through cover.
key_messages: Your backlift is nicely compact — that’s perfect for a classical cover drive.
You’re getting forward onto the front foot through the swing, which supports timing.
Your swing is arm-led, and that’s totally fine for a placement cover drive.
Next step: make the front leg feel a bit ‘taller’ through the hit so you don’t lose your line.

phase_by_phase_story.P0: You start with a steady base and a fairly upright body, which sets you up to play late and under control.
phase_by_phase_story.P2: The bat pick-up is compact — good for getting into position without over-committing, so you can still adjust to the ball.
phase_by_phase_story.P3: You move forward onto the front foot and swing with the arms leading — good for placing the ball — but the front leg stays a bit ‘soft’, which can make the bat drift across the line.

what_to_tell_the_player.P2: Pick it up compact and calm — feel like the bat stays close to you.
what_to_tell_the_player.P3: Step, get tall on the front leg, then swing through the line — don’t let the front knee keep sinking.
what_to_tell_the_player.overall: Control first: stable head, smooth forward move, and a straight swing through extra cover.

P2: Bat pick-up stays close and near-vertical, without a big laid-back lift.
P3: Front leg firms up through the hit instead of 'sinking' as the bat comes down.
